caption: TABLE I: Comparison with baseline on COCO val2017. We report the number of parameters and FLOPs of the backbone. Underline indicates FLOPs or metrics on par with the baseline. APbsuperscriptAPb\rm AP^{b}roman_AP start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and APmsuperscriptAPm\rm AP^{m}roman_AP start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represent box AP and mask AP, respectively.
description: Table I presents a comparison of the proposed PIIP model with baseline models (ViTDet-B and ViTDet-L) on the COCO val2017 dataset for object detection.  The table shows the number of parameters and FLOPs (floating point operations) for each model's backbone.  Performance is measured using Average Precision (AP) for both bounding boxes (APb) and segmentation masks (APm).  The results are presented for both 50 and 75 thresholds.  Underlined values highlight cases where the proposed PIIP model achieves comparable or better results than the baselines, demonstrating its efficiency gains in terms of FLOPs while maintaining competitive accuracy.

caption: TABLE II: Performance of CNN-based and heterogeneous models on COCO val2017.
description: This table presents a comparison of the performance of different backbone architectures on the COCO val2017 dataset for object detection.  It contrasts models using only CNNs (ConvNeXt) against models that utilize Vision Transformers (ViTs) or a combination of both (heterogeneous models). The results show the performance (APb and APm) and computational cost (#FLOPs) for each model at a 1024-pixel image resolution, indicating the effectiveness of PIIP (Parameter-Inverted Image Pyramid) in improving performance and reducing computational overhead.

caption:
TABLE III: Object detection and instance segmentation performance on COCO val2017. ‘MS’ means using AutoAugment [71] for multi-scale training. Large-size models use ViT weights trained on ImageNet-21K.
Some results are from [21].
description: Table III presents a comparison of various models' performance on the COCO val2017 dataset for object detection and instance segmentation tasks.  The table shows the Average Precision (AP) scores at different Intersection over Union (IoU) thresholds (AP50, AP75, AP, APm) for each model.  The models include different vision transformers (ViT) and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) based architectures, some of which use the AutoAugment technique [71] for multi-scale training.  Large-size models are trained with ViT weights pretrained on the larger ImageNet-21K dataset. Note that some results are taken from a previous publication [21]. The table helps to demonstrate and compare the performance of various approaches to object detection and instance segmentation.

caption: TABLE IV: Experiments on the large-scale vision foundation model InternViT-6B.
description: This table presents experimental results obtained using the InternViT-6B, a large-scale vision foundation model.  It shows the model's performance on object detection and semantic segmentation tasks using different configurations and compares the results with a baseline. Key metrics reported include Average Precision (AP) for bounding boxes and masks, along with computational costs (FLOPs) and the number of model parameters. The table also indicates the input resolution used for each experiment, allowing for an assessment of the impact of different resolution settings on both performance and computational efficiency.

caption: TABLE X: From-scratch pre-training settings and results on ImageNet-1K.
description: This table details the configuration and performance of a model trained from scratch using the parameter-inverted image pyramid network (PIIP) architecture.  It breaks down the model's structure across three branches, specifying the number of layers, dimensions, number of heads, resolution, and the resulting number of parameters and FLOPs for each. It also lists the final model's performance, namely the top-1 accuracy on ImageNet-1K.

caption: TABLE XI: Comparison with multi-resolution baselines on multimodal benchmarks. All models are trained with LLaVA-1.5 [24] training data. We report #FLOPs of the vision encoder.
description: This table compares the performance of different vision-language models on various multimodal benchmarks.  The models use different multi-resolution approaches for processing images.  All models were trained using the same LLaVA-1.5 training data. The key metrics shown are the performance across multiple benchmarks and the computational cost (#FLOPs) of the vision encoder. This comparison helps to determine the effectiveness of various multi-resolution strategies, particularly concerning the trade-off between performance and computational efficiency.

caption:
TABLE XII: 
Comparison with existing MLLMs on multimodal benchmarks.
“Data” denotes the data size of all training stages.
*Images from SQA-IMG test set are observed in training, so we mark its result and Avg in gray.
description: Table XII presents a comparison of the PIIP-LLaVA model's performance on various multimodal benchmarks against other state-of-the-art Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs).  It highlights the impact of different model architectures, training data sizes, and input resolutions on the performance of these models across diverse tasks such as visual question answering and visual commonsense reasoning.  The table provides a comprehensive overview of PIIP-LLaVA's capabilities, showing that with increased training data and higher resolution, PIIP-LLaVA outperforms other models on several benchmarks, indicating the effectiveness of its approach to multimodal understanding.

caption: TABLE XIII: Ablation on multimodal understanding with CLIP-B, CLIP-L and Vicuna-7B.
description: This table presents the results of ablation studies on the PIIP-LLaVA model for multimodal understanding.  It investigates the impact of varying the number of cross-branch interactions and the extent to which different components of the vision encoder (branches, interactions, or both) are unfrozen during pretraining. The table shows how these choices affect performance across various benchmarks for multimodal understanding, including  MMBench, MMVet, TextVQA, SQA, GQA, VQAv2, SEED, and POPE. The results highlight the optimal configuration for these parameters to achieve the best balance of performance and computational efficiency.

caption: TABLE XIV: Ablation on image pyramid and parameter-inverted design. ‘PI’, ‘IP’ and ‘Inter.’ represent parameter-inverted, image pyramid and interactions. ‘MS’ means multi-scale training, following [71].
description: Table XIV is an ablation study analyzing the impact of different design choices on object detection performance within the PIIP (Parameter-Inverted Image Pyramid) framework. It compares various configurations, including: the absence of an image pyramid, the use of a standard image pyramid, the inclusion of cross-branch interactions, the use of the parameter-inverted design, and different combinations of these.  The results are presented using the Mask R-CNN 1x schedule, measuring APb, APm, and other metrics.  The table aims to demonstrate the contribution of each component of the PIIP design to the overall performance.

caption: TABLE XV: Baseline with higher resolution.
description: This table compares the performance of a large vision model (ViTDet-L) at different input resolutions (1024 vs 1792 pixels) and compares it to the proposed Parameter-Inverted Image Pyramid Network (PIIP-TSBL).  It shows the impact of higher resolution on model performance and computational cost.  The focus is on demonstrating the improved efficiency and effectiveness of PIIP-TSBL, which achieves comparable or better results than ViTDet-L with significantly reduced computational resources.

caption: TABLE XVI: Ablation on attention implementation and number of interactions with PIIP-TSB 1120/896/448.
description: This table presents the results of ablation studies conducted on the PIIP-TSB model (with a resolution of 1120/896/448).  The studies investigated the impact of two different attention mechanisms (regular attention and deformable attention) and varying numbers of interactions (0, 1, 2, 4, 6, 12) on the model's performance.  The metrics reported likely include AP (average precision), possibly broken down by different object size scales (e.g., small, medium, large),  and FLOPs (floating point operations) as a measure of computational cost.  The table aims to determine the optimal combination of attention mechanism and number of interactions that yields the best performance with acceptable computational resources.

content:
Model Resolution #Param #FLOPs Top-1 Acc
ViT-B (our impl.) 224 86M 17.5G 82.0
PIIP-B (ours) 512/256/128 100M 18.4G 82.7
caption: TABLE XVII: Ablation on interaction directions with PIIP-TSB under resolution 1120/896/448.
description: This table presents an ablation study on different interaction patterns within the Parameter-Inverted Image Pyramid Networks (PIIP) architecture, focusing on the impact of varying cross-branch interaction directions. The experiment uses the PIIP-TSB model with a resolution of 1120/896/448, testing five different interaction strategies. For each strategy, the table shows FLOPs (floating point operations), indicating computational cost, and the resulting Average Precision (AP) scores for bounding boxes (APb) and masks (APm) at different Intersection over Union (IoU) thresholds (0.5, 0.75).  The goal is to determine the optimal interaction design for balancing computational efficiency and performance.
